That said, let's jump into the first story of the day.
And the first thing we're gonna talk about today, the most requested story today,
and that is YouTube censorship.
There was an outcry from creators last week and over the weekend,
and it is now gaining a ton of traction.
And you may have already seen some of the headlines:
Or the least clickbaity of the not-happy-about-this headlines,
And so that's the story here. YouTube's Restricted Mode.
If you go into your settings, right there at the top, it says 'Restricted Mode Filter.'
You have two options: 'Don't filter' or 'Strict filter.'
You know, it's like when you order a sandwich.
'Would you like no mayo, or the entire jar?
Nothing in between, because why would offer that as an option?'
So people discovered that this was a thing last week. They tested it out and realized, oh no!
A lot of the channels I watch don't have any videos that I can now view under this mode.
An example, if you put the filter on,
zero of my videos show up. It looks like I have a blank channel.
But for the most part, this story never really blew up to where it's at now
until the LGBT community realized that they were being blocked.
And large creators started being vocal about this.
Tyler Oakley tweeting:
Other creators pointing out that their coming out videos were restricted.
The trans community was also affected. One of the largest creators on this platform, Gigi Gorgeous,
she made a video where she pointed out that YouTube restricted all her videos talking about gender identity.
She goes on to say that the situation is scary. She doesn't think there's any ill intent, but the effect here is very negative.
Saying that for her and many others, YouTube was a place where they felt safe.
Accepted, and felt that they could be proud of who they were.
And one of the most interesting quotes I saw in regards to why people should be angry about this was:
And YouTube responded to this backlash on Twitter, writing:
Now to me, this seems like a vague-on-purpose non-apology that doesn't really explain anything.
And when I reached out to YouTube for a statement, I was forwarded to this
same public statement,
which once again brings us to the biggest problem for YouTube as always, communication.
Now what I will say before talking about my full opinion on this is,
I kind of understand where both sides are coming from.
YouTube's saying, there isn't a big effect here, there's a small selection of users that wanna strictly censor YouTube.
So if you're talking about mature things, sexual things, people can opt in to avoid things like that.
And the big point here is 'opt in.'
This is not the default. There are people that are angry about two separate things.
There are people that are angry about pure age-gating and demonetization of their videos.
And if you've watched my channel for a while, you know all about the demonetization issue.
And that's an issue that's the same for some but separate for most of who are angry about this Restrictive Mode.
Because they're seemingly not publicly demonetized or age-gated, but their videos aren't appearing in Restrictive Mode.
Which YouTube is going to point out time and time again,
it is not the default, it is an opt-in setting.
You're not actually being censored.
You're saying that it only blocks one kind of content, but the actual videos being restricted,
it seems like it was just buckshot.
Whether people are talking about sexual prosthetics or they're just talking about coming out.
It's being restricted, so if I'm just talking about myself and my life,
you're restricting me. You're saying I'm not suitable for everyone.
And then other creators out there saying, 'Well, also, why are my videos being blocked under Restricted Mode?'
Their explanation doesn't really make sense. Especially when, even my last video,
where I was like, 'Sorry, guys, I'm not- I'm not here right now.
Not gonna make a video this week.' Even that was blocked under their Restricted Mode.
Which, once again, in this scenario, I'm not personally complaining.
I just think this is classic YouTube handling the situation in the worst possible way.
I tried to get more answers, they didn't give me more answers.
I'd love to know, when they're saying that YouTube Restricted Mode is meant to handle mature content,
so are we saying this content is 18+?
Is it just not teen-friendly? Are we talking anyone over the age of 3+?
Because if you're talking about the very young kids,
why even include this mode? There's already an app called YouTube Kids, it's massive.
Millions and millions of parents out there trust their kids with this app because of their parental restrictions.
So who exactly are you trying to protect here?
It is very un-YouTube to try and do something for one to four percent of the people that use YouTube.
And to also, if possible, give us answers. If you're rating our channels as kid-friendly, teen-friendly, or mature,
why not just let us know where we're ranked?
Let us know what content we put out that got us there.
So at least there are examples, and it doesn't feel like you're just switching things up.
And let us know, is there a way to get a different rating over time?
If there's more than a certain number of videos that are dinged mature,
is that why certain channels are then completely blank under Restricted Mode?
And just talk to your creators. As a company, it is okay to say you're testing something and admit fault.
The only filter settings you have are 'none' and 'strict.'
And if you just said, 'We're testing out this new thing, we only have two extremes of it right now.
Thank you for letting us know something was wrong.'
Or, 'No. We as a company have decided that these topics, these discussions, are not for-'
Tell us where your age range is. It's not appropriate for 17 and under, 13 and under, 4 and under.
Give people answers or they will assume the worst.
Because that's what human beings do. When we don't have information, we fill in the blanks with the worst possible scenario.
When I was 17 and my girlfriend didn't call me one night,
my mind automatically said, 'No, she's probably not asleep.
She's having a train run on her, or found out that her father was in the hospital that night.'
But the main point that I wanna get across in this story is,
I understand why there is so much concern, there is so much outrage.
But I also don't believe that YouTube is trying to do anything bad here.
I think what we're seeing here is poor execution, explanation, and communication in general.
And it's also important to remember that it's not just the LGBT community that's affected here.
A big part of this conversation is putting people that live a different life,
or have different thoughts, into an 'other' category.
A category that is seen as different, treated as such, and is potentially in the early stages of being withheld,
or more easily withheld, from people.
But of course, that said, this is the Philip DeFranco Show.
It's not just me telling you the news, and giving my opinion. I wanna know what you're thinking.

Do you understand why some the videos should be restricted?

uh, fair-skinned people with the long hair smoking out of peace pipes.'

get rid of fucking Columbus Day.

maybe let's call it something else, 'cause fuck that guy.

Then in Internet privacy news, it seems that we may be on the edge of another huge nude photo leak.
Many people saying this could be the Fappening 2.0.
And you might remember the events that are now called the Fappening that happened back in 2014.
Tons of female stars had their personal, private photos blasted out on the Internet.
You had Jennifer Lawrence, Lea Michele, Victoria Justice,
McKayla Maroney, and reportedly those photos are from when she was underage.
It was one of the biggest, craziest stories of 2014.
And now, in the past week, we've got the news that Emma Watson, Amanda Seyfried,
they had their personal photos posted to the Internet.
Emma Watson's included photos where she was wearing clothes, they say that those were real.
And as far as the nude photos, Emma Watson's team said that those are not her.
Seyfried, on the other hand, it appears that those photos were real.
They show her both nude and in intimate moments.
And now other photos and videos of other stars are being released.
Sean Penn's daughter, Rose McGowan, Sami Miro,
Katie Cassidy, Paige from the WWE.
And these are just the women that have been hit so far.
There are posts alleging that many, many more will be revealed soon.

in these scenarios than many of the women in 2014.

you had pure sexualization, objectification of wrestlers like Trish Stratus.

and then just seeing the reaction around these leaks,
it blows my mind that there's this much support.

things are slowly changing.
